moves.1. c4:
The second in my series of disastrous oversights, this one shows the power of the diagonal.

I've recently been experimenting with the English so I decided to carry on in this game
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e4: I'm not overly familiar with e4 here so I decided to give it a go
moves.4... Nc6 5. Be2: I'm not sure it wouldn't have been better to fianchetto my lsb
moves.7... Qc7 8. Bg5: Looking to delay Bd6 as I figured black was looking to castle kingside and wouldn't want his pawns disrupted
moves.8... Be7 9. Qd2 O-O 10. d4: Hoping for, though not expecting to be able to push this pawn to d5
moves.10... cxd4 11. Nxd4 Nxd4 12. Qxd4 Bc5 13: Looking to boot the black dsb away with b4
moves.14... h6 15. Bh4 Bd6 16. Nb5: Intended as a distraction from the threat of Bxh2, Bg3 looks better now
moves.16... Bxh2+ 17. Kh1: black is now forced to move his queen which means I can grab his dsb, possibly by g3 first.
moves.17... Qf4 18. g3: Whites position is pretty precarious now, black is threatening Bxe3 gaining the white queen
moves.18... Qxe4+ 19. Kxh2:
This is my fatal blunder, although I had seen the possibility of Qh1, I managed to totally overlook the equally obvious Qg2. Better here would have been to exchange queens then I could have grabbed blacks dsb for the loss of my rook on b1.

Thanks for reading please comment

gameName: How to lose at chess pt 2
